items.title: Israelis and Palestinians celebrate as truce brings hope of ‘era of peace’
items.standfirst: UN warns Gaza still needs ‘lifesaving aid’ as world leaders gather in Sharm el-Sheikh to discuss 20-point proposalThere was a rare moment of joy among Israelis and Palestinians on Monday as Hamas released the remaining 20 living hostages in Gaza as part of a swap deal for nearly 2,000 Palestinian detainees, on a day world leaders met in Egypt to try to ensure the current limited truce is extended into a durable peace.“The prayers of millions have finally been answered,” Donald Trump declared at the peace summit, with his counterparts lined up behind him. “At long last, we have peace in the Middle East.” Continue reading...
items.content: UN warns Gaza still needs ‘lifesaving aid’ as world leaders gather in Sharm el-Sheikh to discuss 20-point proposalThere was a rare moment of joy among Israelis and Palestinians on Monday as Hamas released the remaining 20 living hostages in Gaza as part of a swap deal for nearly 2,000 Palestinian detainees, on a day world leaders met in Egypt to try to ensure the current limited truce is extended into a durable peace.“The prayers of millions have finally been answered,” Donald Trump declared at the peace summit, with his counterparts lined up behind him. “At long last, we have peace in the Middle East.” Continue reading...

items.title: Trump sets sights on peace with Iran as he hails ‘end of Gaza war’
items.standfirst: In speech to Israeli Knesset hours after hostages released, US president spoke of ‘historic dawn of new Middle East’Donald Trump has vowed to use the power of his presidency to ensure that Israel recognises it has achieved “all that it can by force of arms”, and begin an age of cooperation in the Middle East that may ultimately extend as far as peace with Iran.In a speech to the Israeli Knesset, made hours after the last remaining Israeli hostages were released from Gaza, Trump hailed the “historic dawn of a new Middle East” and an end to the “long and painful nightmare” of the Gaza war. Continue reading...
items.content: In speech to Israeli Knesset hours after hostages released, US president spoke of ‘historic dawn of new Middle East’Donald Trump has vowed to use the power of his presidency to ensure that Israel recognises it has achieved “all that it can by force of arms”, and begin an age of cooperation in the Middle East that may ultimately extend as far as peace with Iran.In a speech to the Israeli Knesset, made hours after the last remaining Israeli hostages were released from Gaza, Trump hailed the “historic dawn of a new Middle East” and an end to the “long and painful nightmare” of the Gaza war. items.title: Donald Trump praises role played by Egyptian President in Gaza deal
items.standfirst: Trump praised Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi's on October 13, 2025 as the two leaders appeared together before an international summit on the Gaza deal. "He played a very important role" in talks with Hamas. "I appreciate it very much," Trump said of Sisi, whom he called as a powerful leader who keeps crime down in his country.
items.content: Trump praised Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi's on October 13, 2025 as the two leaders appeared together before an international summit on the Gaza deal. "He played a very important role" in talks with Hamas. "I appreciate it very much," Trump said of Sisi, whom he called as a powerful leader who keeps crime down in his country.

items.title: Trump’s speech: “The long and painful nightmare is over”
items.standfirst: US Donald Trump told the Israeli parliament on Monday that the Gaza ceasefire deal he helped broker marked a "historic dawn of a new Middle East". Trump arrived in Israel as Hamas liberated all 20 living Israeli hostages and several Palestinian prisoners were released from Israeli jails under the first phase of the truce plan.
items.content: US Donald Trump told the Israeli parliament on Monday that the Gaza ceasefire deal he helped broker marked a "historic dawn of a new Middle East". Trump arrived in Israel as Hamas liberated all 20 living Israeli hostages and several Palestinian prisoners were released from Israeli jails under the first phase of the truce plan.

items.title: Leaders gather around Donald Trump in Sharm El-Sheikh for Middle East peace summit
items.standfirst: World leaders, led by President Donald Trump and Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi, gathered in Sharm El-Sheikh for a crucial Middle East peace summit. The meeting aims to build on the recent US-brokered ceasefire between Israel and Hamas and pave the way for lasting stability in the region. FRANCE 24's journalist analyse Trump's speech and the stakes of the summit.
items.content: World leaders, led by President Donald Trump and Egyptian President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi, gathered in Sharm El-Sheikh for a crucial Middle East peace summit. The meeting aims to build on the recent US-brokered ceasefire between Israel and Hamas and pave the way for lasting stability in the region. FRANCE 24's journalist analyse Trump's speech and the stakes of the summit.

items.title: Worlds leaders gather in Egypt to back Gaza ceasefire plan
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump arrived in Egypt Monday for a global summit on Gaza’s future, following his visit to Israel to mark a US-brokered ceasefire with Hamas. His trip, including a speech at the Knesset in Jerusalem, comes amid hopes to end two years of conflict between Israel and Hamas. Over two dozen countries will attend the summit hosted by Trump and Egypt’s President el-Sissi. Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu declined, citing a nearby Jewish holiday.
items.content: President Donald Trump arrived in Egypt Monday for a global summit on Gaza’s future, following his visit to Israel to mark a US-brokered ceasefire with Hamas. His trip, including a speech at the Knesset in Jerusalem, comes amid hopes to end two years of conflict between Israel and Hamas. Over two dozen countries will attend the summit hosted by Trump and Egypt’s President el-Sissi. Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu declined, citing a nearby Jewish holiday.

items.title: Israeli hostages return home after two years in captivity
items.standfirst: The 20 remaining living Israeli hostages held in Gaza have now been reunited with their families, after Hamas released them as part of the ceasefire deal. The bodies of 28 hostages killed in Gaza are also set to be returned to their families.
items.content: The 20 remaining living Israeli hostages held in Gaza have now been reunited with their families, after Hamas released them as part of the ceasefire deal. The bodies of 28 hostages killed in Gaza are also set to be returned to their families.

items.title: Hamas releases all living hostages and Israel frees prisoners under Gaza deal
items.standfirst: Ramallah in the West Bank and Tel Aviv in Israel are filled with families gathered for the return of their loved ones. With around 20 Israeli hostages released and nearly 1,900 Palestinian prisoners freed, the end of the war has stirred deep emotions on both sides, as our reporters reveal.
items.content: Ramallah in the West Bank and Tel Aviv in Israel are filled with families gathered for the return of their loved ones. With around 20 Israeli hostages released and nearly 1,900 Palestinian prisoners freed, the end of the war has stirred deep emotions on both sides, as our reporters reveal.

items.title: Palestinians welcome released prisoners as part of Gaza ceasefire agreement
items.standfirst: Cheers erupted in Ramallah, West Bank, as Israel released nearly 2,000 prisoners under the Gaza ceasefire deal in exchange for Israeli hostages freed by Hamas. Freed prisoners were warmly welcomed by crowds, but celebrations remained restrained due to restrictions imposed by nearby Israeli settlers, as FRANCE 24's Claire Paccalin details from the crowd.
items.content: Cheers erupted in Ramallah, West Bank, as Israel released nearly 2,000 prisoners under the Gaza ceasefire deal in exchange for Israeli hostages freed by Hamas. Freed prisoners were warmly welcomed by crowds, but celebrations remained restrained due to restrictions imposed by nearby Israeli settlers, as FRANCE 24's Claire Paccalin details from the crowd.

items.title: Main takeaways of Trump's speech to the Israeli parliament
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump hailed an end to Israel's "painful nightmare" in a speech to the Israeli knesset on Monday as the last surviving hostages returned from Gaza and the first Palestinian prisoners were freed under a US-brokered ceasefire. His lightning visit came ahead of a Gaza peace summit in Egypt's Sharm El-Sheikh.
items.content: US President Donald Trump hailed an end to Israel's "painful nightmare" in a speech to the Israeli knesset on Monday as the last surviving hostages returned from Gaza and the first Palestinian prisoners were freed under a US-brokered ceasefire. His lightning visit came ahead of a Gaza peace summit in Egypt's Sharm El-Sheikh.

clusters.title: Madagascar’s embattled leader refuses to resign as unrest deepens
clusters.neutral_headline: Madagascar's president flees country amid unrest

items.title: Madagascar’s embattled leader refuses to resign as unrest deepens
items.standfirst: Madagascar's President Andry Rajoelina said Monday he was in a “safe place” after an assassination attempt, dismissing calls to quit amid worsening unrest that has driven him into hiding. The twice-delayed speech was his first since a mutinous army unit backed anti-government protests and reports he had fled abroad.
items.content: Madagascar's President Andry Rajoelina said Monday he was in a “safe place” after an assassination attempt, dismissing calls to quit amid worsening unrest that has driven him into hiding. The twice-delayed speech was his first since a mutinous army unit backed anti-government protests and reports he had fled abroad.

items.title: Madagascar's president flees country in fear for his life after military rebellion
items.standfirst: Madagascar President Andry Rajoelina called for dialogue "to find a way out of this situation" and said the constitution should be respected.
items.content: Madagascar President Andry Rajoelina called for dialogue "to find a way out of this situation" and said the constitution should be respected.(Image credit: Alexander Joe)

items.title: President of Madagascar flees to ‘safe location’ amid deadly protests
items.standfirst: Andry Rajoelina confirmed his departure on Monday, following reports he had been evacuated by a French aircraft.
items.content: Andry Rajoelina confirmed his departure on Monday, following reports he had been evacuated by a French aircraft.

items.title: Malagasy President Rajoelina says he fled to a "secure location" to "protect his life"
items.standfirst: The current location of Madagascar’s president remains unclear. However, Andry Rajoelina has addressed the nation from an undisclosed location, stating that he is currently in hiding and was forced to flee for his own safety. There are unconfirmed reports that Rajoelina fled in a French military aircraft. Calls for his resignation have intensified after an elite military unit turned against the government at the weekend in support of weeks of youth-led protests. French President Emmanuel Macron said he could not immediately confirm reports that France had helped Rajoelina to flee. In his speech on Monday night, Rajoelina called for the constitution to be invoked to resolve the crisis surrounding his leadership. We speak to opposition MP Mamy Rabenirina to get his perspective on what the military’s support for the protests could mean for Madagascar’s political future.
items.content: The current location of Madagascar’s president remains unclear. However, Andry Rajoelina has addressed the nation from an undisclosed location, stating that he is currently in hiding and was forced to flee for his own safety. There are unconfirmed reports that Rajoelina fled in a French military aircraft. Calls for his resignation have intensified after an elite military unit turned against the government at the weekend in support of weeks of youth-led protests. French President Emmanuel Macron said he could not immediately confirm reports that France had helped Rajoelina to flee. In his speech on Monday night, Rajoelina called for the constitution to be invoked to resolve the crisis surrounding his leadership. We speak to opposition MP Mamy Rabenirina to get his perspective on what the military’s support for the protests could mean for Madagascar’s political future.

items.title: Madagascar President Rajoelina says he had to leave for a secure location to protect his life
items.standfirst: Madagascar's president Andry Rajoelina said on Monday that he had to move to a safe place to protect his life, following weeks of youth protests calling for his resignation. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Dr Luke Freeman of University College London says that Rajoelina, despite first coming to power by championing reform, 'hasn't been able to address the root problems' of Madagascar, instead focusing on 'vanity projects'.
items.content: Madagascar's president Andry Rajoelina said on Monday that he had to move to a safe place to protect his life, following weeks of youth protests calling for his resignation. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Dr Luke Freeman of University College London says that Rajoelina, despite first coming to power by championing reform, 'hasn't been able to address the root problems' of Madagascar, instead focusing on 'vanity projects'.

items.title: Madagascar president hiding in 'safe place' as he warns of coup attempt
items.standfirst: Andry Rajoelina is said to have fled the country by French military jet but his whereabouts are unknown.
items.content: Andry Rajoelina is said to have fled the country by French military jet but his whereabouts are unknown.

items.title: Madagascar’s President Andry Rajoelina has left the country, French radio reports
items.standfirst: Madagascar's President Andry Rajoelina left the country on Sunday evening after factions of the army rallied behind the protesters who have been staging weeks of demonstrations, FRANCE 24 sister station Radio France Internationale (RFI) reported on Monday.
items.content: Madagascar's President Andry Rajoelina left the country on Sunday evening after factions of the army rallied behind the protesters who have been staging weeks of demonstrations, FRANCE 24 sister station Radio France Internationale (RFI) reported on Monday.

items.title: Madagascar president flees after losing support of key army unit
items.standfirst: Elite Capsat unit that played a major role in Andry Rajoelina’s rise to presidency joined gen Z protests against corruptionMadagascar’s president, Andry Rajoelina, is reported to have fled the country on a French military aircraft, hours before he was scheduled to address the people.French state radio RFI reported on Monday that the president, who also has French citizenship, had been flown out of the capital, Antananarivo, after a deal with President Emmanuel Macron. It added that he may have headed for Dubai. Continue reading...

items.title: Madagascar’s president says illegal power grab by military is under way
items.standfirst: Soldiers from elite Capsat unit have announced they are taking over after weeks of youth-led protestsMadagascar’s president said an “attempt to seize power illegally and by force” was under way, as an elite military unit that joined protesters on the streets on Saturday announced it was taking over the army.The Capsat unit’s intervention comes after weeks of youth-led protests, which started on 25 September against water and electricity shortages and expanded to calling for the resignation of the president, Andry Rajoelina, an end to corruption and radical overhaul of the political system. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Trio of researchers share Nobel in economics for "explaining innovation-driven growth"
items.standfirst: The 2025 Nobel economics prize went to Joel Mokyr, Philippe Aghion, and Peter Howitt for "explaining innovation-driven growth". They are credited with quantifying "creative destruction", an idea that innovations such as steam engines and artificial intelligence that push out older technologies and businesses can be beneficial to humanity in the long run. Plus, in an unprecedented move, the Dutch government took control of Chinese-owned chipmaker Nexperia over national security concerns.
items.content: The 2025 Nobel economics prize went to Joel Mokyr, Philippe Aghion, and Peter Howitt for "explaining innovation-driven growth". They are credited with quantifying "creative destruction", an idea that innovations such as steam engines and artificial intelligence that push out older technologies and businesses can be beneficial to humanity in the long run. Plus, in an unprecedented move, the Dutch government took control of Chinese-owned chipmaker Nexperia over national security concerns.

items.title: Trio wins economics Nobel for work on tech-driven growth
items.standfirst: The Nobel prize in economics was awarded on Monday to American-Israeli Joel Mokyr, France's Philippe Aghion and Canada's Peter Howitt for work on how technology drives and affects growth. Mokyr, 79, won one half of the prize "for having identified the prerequisites for sustained growth through technological progress", the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences said. Aghion, 69, and Howitt, 79, shared the other half "for the theory of sustained growth through creative destruction", it added.
items.content: The Nobel prize in economics was awarded on Monday to American-Israeli Joel Mokyr, France's Philippe Aghion and Canada's Peter Howitt for work on how technology drives and affects growth. Mokyr, 79, won one half of the prize "for having identified the prerequisites for sustained growth through technological progress", the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences said. Aghion, 69, and Howitt, 79, shared the other half "for the theory of sustained growth through creative destruction", it added.

ai_summary: Joel Mokyr, Philippe Aghion, and Peter Howitt won the Nobel Prize.
They were recognized for work on how technology drives growth.
Mokyr won for identifying prerequisites for sustained growth.
Aghion and Howitt shared the prize for the theory of growth.
The prize was awarded for work on innovation-driven growth.

items.content: Cuban dissident Jose Daniel Ferrer vowed Monday to keep fighting for democracy after being freed from prison and exiled to the United States. After landing in Miami from the communist-run island, Washington urged Cuba to release over 700 political prisoners still behind bars.

items.standfirst: Ferrer, who has been imprisoned repeatedly, says he opted for exile after facing ‘torture’ behind bars in CubaThe prominent Cuban dissident José Daniel Ferrer has been freed from prison and put on a plane to the US where he will live in exile with his family, the communist country’s foreign ministry has said.Ferrer, who has been imprisoned repeatedly as the long-term leader of the island’s pro-democracy movement, announced this month he had opted for exile after facing “torture” and “humiliation” behind bars. Continue reading...
items.content: Ferrer, who has been imprisoned repeatedly, says he opted for exile after facing ‘torture’ behind bars in CubaThe prominent Cuban dissident José Daniel Ferrer has been freed from prison and put on a plane to the US where he will live in exile with his family, the communist country’s foreign ministry has said.Ferrer, who has been imprisoned repeatedly as the long-term leader of the island’s pro-democracy movement, announced this month he had opted for exile after facing “torture” and “humiliation” behind bars. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Cuban dissident José Daniel Ferrer was freed from prison and exiled to the US.
Ferrer announced he opted for exile after facing "torture" in prison.
He will live in exile with his family in the United States.
Washington urged Cuba to release over 700 political prisoners.
Ferrer is a long-term leader of the island’s pro-democracy movement.

items.title: Amazon Aims to Hire 250,000 Holiday Season Workers, Same as 2024

clusters.title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy ordered to go to jail next week
clusters.neutral_headline: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy ordered to go to jail next week

items.title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy ordered to go to jail next week
items.standfirst: Sarkozy must go to La Santé prison in Paris after conviction over scheme to obtain election funds from Gaddafi regimeThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been ordered to go to jail in Paris next week after a court last month sentenced him to five years in prison for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to obtain election campaign funds from the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi.Sarkozy, who was the rightwing president of France between 2007 and 2012, was summoned to meet state prosecutors on Monday. They told him he must present himself at the entrance of La Santé prison in the south of Paris on 21 October to begin his sentence. Continue reading...
items.content: Sarkozy must go to La Santé prison in Paris after conviction over scheme to obtain election funds from Gaddafi regimeThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has been ordered to go to jail in Paris next week after a court last month sentenced him to five years in prison for criminal conspiracy over a scheme to obtain election campaign funds from the regime of the late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi.Sarkozy, who was the rightwing president of France between 2007 and 2012, was summoned to meet state prosecutors on Monday. They told him he must present himself at the entrance of La Santé prison in the south of Paris on 21 October to begin his sentence. Continue reading...

items.title: Former president Sarkozy to begin serving five-year prison sentence Oct 21, French media reports
items.standfirst: French prosecutors on Monday told former French president Nicolas Sarkozy that he must report to a Paris prison on October 21 to begin serving a five-year sentence for illegally accepting funds from late Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi to fund his 2007 presidential run.
items.content: French prosecutors on Monday told former French president Nicolas Sarkozy that he must report to a Paris prison on October 21 to begin serving a five-year sentence for illegally accepting funds from late Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi to fund his 2007 presidential run.

ai_summary: Nicolas Sarkozy must begin his prison sentence on October 21.
He was convicted over a scheme to obtain election funds.
Sarkozy was sentenced to five years in prison.
He was summoned to meet state prosecutors on Monday.
The funds were from the late Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi.

items.title: Markets rebound amid latest US-China tariff spat as traders look to possible ‘Taco trade’
items.standfirst: US S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes rise and cryptocurrencies rebound after Trump post on Truth SocialBusiness live – latest updatesGlobal stock markets have edged higher and cryptocurrencies rebounded amid signs that a new front in the US-China trade war may not be as severe as first feared.Tensions between Washington and Beijing escalated again on Friday and over the weekend, as Donald Trump threatened to impose additional US tariffs of 100% on China starting next month. Continue reading...
items.content: US S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes rise and cryptocurrencies rebound after Trump post on Truth SocialBusiness live – latest updatesGlobal stock markets have edged higher and cryptocurrencies rebounded amid signs that a new front in the US-China trade war may not be as severe as first feared.Tensions between Washington and Beijing escalated again on Friday and over the weekend, as Donald Trump threatened to impose additional US tariffs of 100% on China starting next month. Continue reading...

items.title: China warns US of retaliation over Trump’s 100% tariffs threat
items.standfirst: Beijing says it will act if US president doesn’t stand down, while investors brace for trade war turmoilBeijing has told the US it will retaliate if Donald Trump fails to back down on his threat to impose 100% tariffs on Chinese imports as investors brace for another bout of trade war turmoil.China’s commerce ministry blamed Washington for raising trade tensions between the two countries after Trump announced on Friday that he would impose the additional tariffs on China’s exports to the US, along with new controls on critical software, by 1 November. Continue reading...
items.content: Beijing says it will act if US president doesn’t stand down, while investors brace for trade war turmoilBeijing has told the US it will retaliate if Donald Trump fails to back down on his threat to impose 100% tariffs on Chinese imports as investors brace for another bout of trade war turmoil.China’s commerce ministry blamed Washington for raising trade tensions between the two countries after Trump announced on Friday that he would impose the additional tariffs on China’s exports to the US, along with new controls on critical software, by 1 November. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Global stock markets and cryptocurrencies have edged higher.
Donald Trump threatened 100% tariffs on Chinese imports.
China warned the US of retaliation if tariffs are imposed.
The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes rose.
Tensions between the US and China escalated again.
